posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
I’m in the middle of trying to resolve out of memory issues on the roboRIO.

Adding a swap partition on a USB drive is working as a quick fix.

In spite of the swap partition being listed in /etc/fstab, the swap partition is not being used at system startup; I need to hand issue a swapon -a . I suspect the swapon -a in the startup procs is being issued before the USB is fully up.

In the old days, I could put stuff into /etc/rc.local on my Unices. Is the equivalent available on the roboRIO, or do I have to write my owner rcS.d script?

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: These days a udev rule to take action is probably the most proper.  Something along the lines of this is what I’m thinking. Add a udev rule to run a script when usb is un/plugged - Debian User Forums

link_counts.title: Add a udev rule to run a script when usb is un/plugged - Debian User Forums

posts.name: Shorya Malani
posts.cooked: Would it be possible to allocate some of the storage of the rio as swap, I feel like USB’s can get unplugged during matches which would be really unfortunate if it led to a dead code.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
yes, swapping to onboard flash is possible.

the flash memory only has a limited number of writes in it’s lifetime, and swapping has the ability to tear through those pretty fast. I’d hate to kill a roboRIO because I wore out the flash.

Flash memory wear due to excessive data logging appears to be killing older Tesla's, and it only seems to be a matter of time until the new ones die, too.

link_counts.title: Flash Memory Wear Killing Older Tesla's Due to Excessive Data Logging: Report | Tom's Hardware

posts.name: Shorya Malani
posts.cooked: Hmm, thats fair, but not playing a match is about $200 plus opportunity cost while rios are about $500 so I think that might be a sacrifice I am willing to make instead of risking matches.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
yeah, I agree.

but this is just a workaround until I get to the root cause of the issue; hopefully resolved before first match.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Recommend disabling the NI web server to reclaim some memory. The RoboRIO Team Number Setter can do this: roboRIO Team Number Setter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: roboRIO Team Number Setter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Shorya Malani
posts.cooked: I did this and then the work around by changing the script running lvrt, however that ended up forcing me to run robot code from the terminal :(. Unfortunately, I am still often running out of memory.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: roboRIO 2’s generally don’t have memory issues. They have double the memory, and the storage is on the SD card. If you’re willing to sacrifice the $500, you can buy a roboRIO 2, which likely won’t have low memory issues, and also you could put swap on the SD card, which is easily replacable.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: We can, and we may. I am reluctant to use it for competition; saw lot’s of trouble with them at the events I CSAd at. I’ll use them if I can’t get a roboRIO to be reliable.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
fovea1959:

do I have to write my owner rcS.d script?

Done as admin:

Wrote /etc/init.d/addswap.sh:

Added to the sysv init scheme: update-rc.d -v addswap.sh defaults

Added a line to bottom of /etc/fstab:

Put a thumb drive in that has a swap partition as the first one.

Reboot.

I have swap space.
